    A crash course on gravity models

    Mauricio Vargas

    2018-10-11

    crash-course-on-gravity-models.Rmd

    To estimate gravity equations you need a square dataset including bilateral flows defined by the argument , ISO codes or similar of type character (e.g. for the country of origin and for the destination country), a distance measure defined by the argument and other potential influences (e.g. contiguity and common currency) given as a vector in are required.

    All dummy variables should be of type numeric (0/1). Make sure the origin and destination codes are of type “character”. If an independent variable is defined as a ratio, it should be logged. The user should perform some data cleaning beforehand to remove observations that contain entries that can distort estimates. The functions will remove zero flows and distances.

    containing a measure of distance between all pairs of bilateral partners and bilateral variables that should be taken as the independent variables in the estimation.

    For estimating gravity equations via Bonus Vetus OLS see

    For more information on gravity models, theoretical foundations and estimation methods in general see

    and the citations therein.

    See for gravity datasets and Stata code for estimating gravity models.
